item.title: ArtsBeat: Hopi Masks Sold at Auction After Judge’s Ruling
item.description: The auction in Paris was fiercely contested by the Hopi tribe of northeastern Arizona and generated more than $1 million in sales.
item.dc:creator: By TOM MASHBERG
item.media:description: Bo Lomahquahu, center, with other protesters outside the auction on Friday.

item.title: Rights Groups Question Legality of Targeted Killing
item.description: A nine-page letter sent to President Obama is the most significant critique to date of what has become the centerpiece of the United States’ counterterrorism efforts.
item.dc:creator: By SCOTT SHANE

item.title: Taliban Attack Afghan Army Unit
item.description: Insurgents dealt a serious blow to a battalion in eastern Afghanistan on Friday, killing 13 soldiers and overrunning their outpost.
item.dc:creator: By ROD NORDLAND and AZAM AHMED

item.title: Bailout Terms Eased for Ireland and Portugal
item.description: Euro zone finance ministers agreed to give Ireland and Portugal more time to repay their bailout loans after a rescue for Cyprus renewed animosity toward the authorities overseeing the single currency area.
item.dc:creator: By JAMES KANTER
item.media:description: Jeroen Dijsselbloem, the president of the so-called Eurogroup of ministers, spoke to members of the media at a meeting of finance ministers in Dublin, Ireland, on Friday.

item.title: India Ink: In Delhi, Even My Own Car Is No Refuge From Harassment
item.description: Driving in a private vehicle through the streets of Delhi, in broad daylight, is no guarantee that a woman will escape harassment.
item.dc:creator: By PAMPOSH RAINA
item.media:description: A woman driving a car on the outskirts of New Delhi.

item.title: Cameron and Merkel to Discuss British Role in Bloc
item.description: The leaders of Britain and Germany have begun a “not purely routine” weekend visit to discuss Britain’s future in the European Union.
item.dc:creator: By MELISSA EDDY and STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: WORLD: Chávez's Lasting Impact
item.description: Even in death, former leader Hugo Chávez plays an omnipresent role in Venezuela's presidential campaigns as voters prepare to elect their new leader on Sunday.

item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: April 12
item.description: A wholesale fruit market in Hyderabad, Andhra Pradesh.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: Workers sorting mangoes at a wholesale fruit market in Hyderabad, Andhra Pradesh.

item.title: U.S. Issues Penalties Against Russians for Rights Violations
item.description: The Obama administration issued sanctions against about two dozen Russians but avoided targeting many high-level figures in President Vladimir Putin’s government.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By PETER BAKER

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: In the Hytner Era, the National Theater Hit Its Mark
item.description: Starting with “Jerry Springer: The Opera,” Nicholas Hytner has repositioned the three-stage complex as arguably the defining theatrical address in the English-speaking world. And he still has two years to go.
item.dc:creator: By MATT WOLF
item.media:credit: Jonathan Player for The New York Times
item.media:description: Nicholas Hytner in 2004, early in his tenure at the National Theater in London.

item.title: Letter from Europe: Public Lies That Sap Public Trust
item.description: Perhaps more than the crimes that politicians in Britain and France are discovered to have committed, it is the lies that undermine public confidence in government.
item.dc:creator: By CELESTINE BOHLEN

item.title: French Senate Passes Same-Sex Marriage Bill
item.description: A final vote on the legislation is scheduled for next week in the lower house of Parliament, where the bill is expected to pass.
item.category: Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships
item.dc:creator: By SCOTT SAYARE

item.title: Tobacco That’s So Brooklyn but Made in Belgium
item.description: Deep in the Ardennes, there’s a man who lives out of time, tending a strange, near-mythic tobacco as if life depended on the pleasure of a pipe.
item.dc:creator: By WIL S. HYLTON

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: France Debates the Merits of the Bra
item.description: A French scientist suggests women might be better off without their bras. His findings have prompted a debate about the pros and cons of the lingerie item, tempered with some notes of Gallic humor.
item.dc:creator: By HARVEY MORRIS
item.media:description: Employees of the French lingerie maker Lejaby in 2012 with a patriotic example of their handiwork.

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: Britain to Go After Companies Exploiting Unpaid Interns
item.description: For many young workers, the only hope of starting out in a career is to take an unpaid internship. But some companies are getting something for nothing — with as many as 100,000 people working without pay in Britain alone.
item.dc:creator: By HARVEY MORRIS
item.media:credit: Deidre Schoo for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ross Perlin, author of "Intern Nation: How to Earn Nothing and Learn Little in the Brave New Economy," in his Brooklyn apartment.

item.title: Gay Marriage Law Advances in France
item.description: The French Senate voted to legalize same-sex marriage, putting a landmark bill on track to become law by summer.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: In Seoul, Kerry Warns North Korea Against Missile Test
item.description: Secretary of State John Kerry warned North Korea not to test-fire its Musudan missile and said the nation would lose if a conflict broke out.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON and CHOE SANG-HUN
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Paul J. Richards
item.media:description: Secretary of State John Kerry, center, with President Park Geun-hye of South Korea, right, in Seoul on Friday.

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: IHT Quick Read: April 12
item.description: Worries about the H7N9 bird flu; Russia bets on methane-powered cars; deeper debt for Cyprus; and “Django Unchained” is pulled from Chinese theaters.
item.dc:creator: By THE INTERNATIONAL HERALD TRIBUNE
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: Buses powered by natural gas refueling at a station on the outskirts of Moscow.

item.title: At War Blog: Finding Closure Through ‘Zero Dark Thirty’
item.description: After the initial adrenaline and shock faded, an officer felt pride – as well as guilt for having killed an insurgent.
item.dc:creator: By HUGH MILLER
item.media:description: Hugh Miller in Qandaro Village in Pech District, Afghanistan.

item.title: French Court Allows Auction of American Indian Artifacts
item.description: A judge rejected a challenge by the Hopi tribe of northeastern Arizona, despite the group’s contention that the artifacts were sacred, communally owned objects.
item.dc:creator: By NICOLA CLARK
item.media:credit: Art et Communication, via European Pressphoto Agency
item.media:description: A Hopi mask that will be up for auction on Friday.

item.title: India Ink: Harassed While Driving? What the Law Says
item.description: There are several laws that cover harassment of women in their cars.
item.dc:creator: By PAMPOSH RAINA
item.media:description: Policemen standing outside Tihar Jail in New Delhi on March 11.

item.title: China Defends Vaccination of Poultry as Flu Spreads
item.description: China’s Agriculture Ministry said its policy of poultry vaccination for the H5N1 virus was not interfering with its efforts to identify the H7N9 virus.
item.dc:creator: By KEITH BRADSHER

item.title: Mystery Surrounds Withdrawal of ‘Django Unchained’ in China
item.description: No official reason was given for the decision to suspend “Django Unchained,” but there was talk among the industry that brief nudity had offended Chinese officials.
item.dc:creator: By GERRY MULLANY and MICHAEL CIEPLY
item.media:description: A poster in Beijing for “Django Unchained.” No reason was given for halting the showings.

item.title: IHT Rendezvous: Story of Women’s Labor Camp Abuse Unnerves Even China
item.description: A woman’s diary, and a hard-hitting magazine story, cast a spotlight on the conditions at re-education-through-labor camps in China, which government officials have said they will reform.
item.dc:creator: By DIDI KIRSTEN TATLOW
item.media:description: A screengrab from a Sina microblog account, showing torture of female inmates in China, according to a person who posted it.

item.title: Papua New Guinea Considers Repealing Sorcery Law
item.description: The prime minister has vowed to repeal a controversial sorcery act after the latest in a string of brutal public killings of people accused of practicing black magic.
item.dc:creator: By MATT SIEGEL
